awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  AI-Powered Robotic Harvesters for Greenhouse Cultivation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to improve agricultural yields at lower costs.  The proposed Phase II project will advance the development of an autonomous universal harvesting robotic system. By combining artificial intelligence with dexterous robotic systems that physically care for each plant, growers can boost their yields while decreasing operational complexity. 

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will develop critical technologies for robotic agricultural harvesting systems. New machine learning and computer vision techniques will be used to construct three-dimensional models of the growing environment.  These models will inform automatically calculated movement plans for a multi-degree-of-freedom robotic arm that avoids obstacles and items that could entangle the robot.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
As a result of this SBIR Phase II project, Root AI achieved all its technical objectives and a significant commercial development milestone. In the approximately twelve months from April 15th, 2020, to March 31st, 2021, Root AI achieved dramatic improvements on all technical metrics identified as key innovation areas for commercial viability of the Virgo harvesting system. These were: harvesting throughput, fault detection rate, fault automatic recovery rate, first pick success rate, automatic fruit collection and handling, and faster picking cycle times. In each case, the measurable metric meets or, in the case of first pick success rate and picking cycle time, exceeds the needed thresholds for initial commercial viability. These advancements were achieved through close partnership with commercial pilot customers. In total, five extended field trials each operating two Virgo harvesting systems for their maximum daily utilization were executed totaling over 3 months of deployed operations. The continuous and extended pilot operations of these systems enabled Root AI to obtain valuable datasets about operational dynamics and system performance exponentially larger than anything previously recorded. Each dataset contained picking conditions and outcomes for hundreds of thousands of harvested fruits. The technical work conducted in the grant also supported one new provisional filing for new intellectual property, focused on the new system method of operation and fruit collection scheme invented and applied to the harvesting system during the project.

As a result of the harvesting performance improvements achieved through this project, Root AI is in a strong position to expand pilot engagements and early customer partnerships. The critical proof point of reaching productivity rates which are financially compelling using an automated harvesting system has been passed. Cost of ownership improvements will be progressed in parallel with expanded commercial deployment as an area of development focus over the 1-2 years following completion of this project. As a sign of the considerable progress achieved in commercial viability, Root AI was approached toward the end of the project about a complete acquisition of its technology and integration into a leading and publicly traded commercial produce manufacturer. The acquisition by AppHarvest of Root AI and its autonomous harvesting technology was completed in April of 2021.


Last Modified: 05/03/2022
Modified by: Joshua Lessing
